# Database schema

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

The **database schema** of a [database system](/wiki/Database_system "Database
system") is its structure described in a [formal
language](/wiki/Formal_language "Formal language") supported by the [database
management system](/wiki/Database_management_system "Database management
system") (DBMS). The term "[schema](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/schema
"wikt:schema")" refers to the organization of data as a blueprint of how the
database is constructed (divided into database tables in the case of
[relational databases](/wiki/Relational_databases "Relational databases")).
The formal definition of a [database](/wiki/Database "Database") schema is a
set of formulas (sentences) called [integrity
constraints](/wiki/Integrity_constraints "Integrity constraints") imposed on a
database.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] These integrity constraints ensure
compatibility between parts of the schema. All constraints are expressible in
the same language. A database can be considered a structure in realization of
the [database language](/wiki/Database_language "Database language").[1] The
states of a created [conceptual schema](/wiki/Conceptual_schema "Conceptual
schema") are transformed into an [explicit
mapping](/wiki/Explicit_and_implicit_methods "Explicit and implicit methods"),
the database schema. This describes how real-world entities are
[modeled](/wiki/Data_modeling "Data modeling") in the database.

"A database schema specifies, based on the [database
administrator](/wiki/Database_administrator "Database administrator")'s
knowledge of possible applications, the facts that can enter the database, or
those of interest to the possible [end-users](/wiki/End-user "End-user")."[2]
The notion of a database schema plays the same role as the notion of theory in
[predicate calculus](/wiki/Predicate_calculus "Predicate calculus"). A model
of this "theory" closely corresponds to a database, which can be seen at any
instant of time as a [mathematical object](/wiki/Mathematical_object
"Mathematical object"). Thus a schema can contain formulas representing
[integrity constraints](/wiki/Data_integrity#Types_of_integrity_constraints
"Data integrity") specifically for an application and the constraints
specifically for a type of database, all expressed in the same database
language.[1] In a [relational database](/wiki/Relational_database "Relational
database"), the schema defines the [tables](/wiki/Table_\(database\) "Table
\(database\)"), [fields](/wiki/Field_\(computer_science\) "Field \(computer
science\)"), [relationships](/wiki/Relational_model "Relational model"),
[views](/wiki/View_\(database\) "View \(database\)"),
[indexes](/wiki/Index_\(database\) "Index \(database\)"),
[packages](/wiki/Software_package_\(installation\) "Software package
\(installation\)"), [procedures](/wiki/Stored_procedure "Stored procedure"),
[functions](/wiki/Subroutine "Subroutine"),
[queues](/wiki/Queue_\(data_structure\) "Queue \(data structure\)"),
[triggers](/wiki/Database_trigger "Database trigger"), [types](/wiki/Data_type
"Data type"), [sequences](/wiki/Sequence "Sequence"), [materialized
views](/wiki/Materialized_view "Materialized view"),
[synonyms](/wiki/Synonym_\(database\) "Synonym \(database\)"), database links,
[directories](/wiki/Directory_\(file_systems\) "Directory \(file systems\)"),
[XML schemas](/wiki/XML_schema "XML schema"), and other elements.

A database generally stores its schema in a [data
dictionary](/wiki/Data_dictionary "Data dictionary"). Although a schema is
defined in text database language, the term is often used to refer to a
graphical depiction of the database structure. In other words, schema is the
structure of the database that defines the objects in the database.

In an [Oracle Database](/wiki/Oracle_Database "Oracle Database") system, the
term "schema" has a slightly different connotation.

## Contents

  * 1 Ideal requirements for schema integration
  * 2 Example of two schema integrations
  * 3 Oracle database specificity
  * 4 See also
  * 5 References
  * 6 External links

## Ideal requirements for schema
integration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Database_schema&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Ideal requirements for schema integration")]

See also: [Database normalization](/wiki/Database_normalization "Database
normalization")

The requirements listed below influence the detailed structure of schemas that
are produced. Certain applications will not require that all of these
conditions are met, but these four requirements are the most ideal.

Overlap preservation

    Each of the overlapping elements specified in the input mapping is also in a database schema relation.[3]

Extended overlap preservation

    Source-specific elements that are associated with a source’s overlapping elements are passed through to the database schema.[3]

Normalization

    Independent entities and relationships in the source data should not be grouped together in the same relation in the database schema. In particular, source specific schema elements should not be grouped with overlapping schema elements, if the grouping co-locates independent entities or relationships.[3]

Minimality

    If any elements of the database schema are dropped then the database schema is not ideal.[3]

## Example of two schema
integrations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Database_schema&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Example of two schema integrations")]

Suppose we want a mediated (database) schema to integrate two travel
databases, Go-travel and Ok-travel.

**`Go-travel`** has two relations:

    
    
    Go-flight(f-num, time, meal(yes/no))
    Go-price(f-num, date, price)
    

(`f-num` being the flight number)

**`Ok-travel`** has just one relation:

    
    
    Ok-flight(f-num, date, time, price, nonstop(yes/no))
    

The overlapping information in Ok-travel’s and Go-travel’s schemas could be
represented in a mediated schema:[3]

    
    
    Flight(f-num, date, time, price)
    

## Oracle database
specificity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Database_schema&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Oracle database specificity")]

In the context of [Oracle Databases](/wiki/Oracle_Database "Oracle Database"),
a **schema object** is a logical [data storage
structure](/wiki/Database_storage_structures "Database storage
structures").[4]

An Oracle database associates a separate schema with each database
**user**.[5] A schema comprises a collection of schema objects. Examples of
schema objects include:

  * [tables](/wiki/Table_\(database\) "Table \(database\)")
  * [views](/wiki/View_\(database\) "View \(database\)")
  * [sequences](/wiki/Sequence "Sequence")
  * [synonyms](/wiki/Synonym_\(database\) "Synonym \(database\)")
  * [indexes](/wiki/Index_\(database\) "Index \(database\)")
  * clusters
  * database links
  * [snapshots](/wiki/Snapshot_\(computer_storage\) "Snapshot \(computer storage\)")
  * [procedures](/wiki/Stored_procedure "Stored procedure")
  * functions
  * packages

On the other hand, non-schema objects may include:[6]

  * users
  * roles
  * contexts
  * directory objects

Schema objects do not have a one-to-one correspondence to physical files on
disk that store their information. However, [Oracle
databases](/wiki/Oracle_database "Oracle database") store schema objects
logically within a [tablespace](/wiki/Tablespace "Tablespace") of the
database. The data of each object is physically contained in one or more of
the tablespace's [datafiles](/wiki/Datafile "Datafile"). For some objects
(such as tables, indexes, and clusters) a [database
administrator](/wiki/Database_administrator "Database administrator") can
specify how much disk space the Oracle [RDBMS](/wiki/RDBMS "RDBMS") allocates
for the object within the tablespace's datafiles.

There is no necessary relationship between schemas and tablespaces: a
tablespace can contain objects from different schemas, and the objects for a
single schema can reside in different tablespaces.
